Award.AwardTitle: AF:Small:Algorithms for visualizing data with contact graphs and data maps

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop new techniques for visualizing static and dynamic data. Visualization allows us to perceive relationships in large interconnected datasets. While statistics may determine correlations among the data, intuitive visualizations of these correlations helps us frame what questions to ask about the data. Moreover, algorithms for visualizing processes that evolve over time will have applications beyond the traditional uses of information visualization in exploratory data analysis and searching for patterns and trends.

Graphs are often used to capture relationships between objects and visualized as node-link diagrams. Contact graphs provide an alternative and often more intuitive way to visualize planar graphs. In contact graphs, nodes are represented by regions and edges are represented by two regions sharing a common border. Such representation suggests the familiar metaphor of a geographical map. In this research project the PIs will study characterizations of the classes of graphs that admit contact graph representations where nodes have "nice" shapes (e.g., convex, with small complexity, with predetermined areas) and techniques for creating such representations. While contact graphs are restricted to planar graphs, the PIs will extend the notion to general graphs using clustering and embedding methods.

As an integral part of this project, graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in all aspects of the described research activities. This continues a tradition of integrating undergraduates into research projects that are easily accessible and visually appealing. As with past projects, all new software developed will be made available to the broader community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Networks are the central object of interest in many of today’s most important challenges, both in theory and practice. Fundamental questions, from biology and physics to engineering and social sciences, are best stated in the simple and abstract, yet powerful and flexible language of networks made out of nodes (e.g., people) and links between them (e.g., friendships).

Contact representations of networks have a long history dating back to Koebe’s 1936 theorem, which shows that all planar networks can be represented by touching disks; this is also known as a "kissing coins" representation. Both abstract and concrete interpretations of networks have begun to reveal the most intriguing connections between the continuous world of geometry and the discrete world of combinatorial structures (see Image "Contact Representation"). Having a geometric representation is much more than just a way to display a network. It reveals underlying structures which can often be described only using geometry. Moreover, every connection between a class of networks and a class of arrangements of geometric objects unlocks an entire theory on the other side, that might already have more powerful tools and machinery. The main results of this project were new bridges between geometry and combinatorics in the context of 2D and 3D contact representations of networks. 

Our results are described in a dozen peer­-reviewed journal publications. The research topic was discussed in a week-long seminar on the topic: "Putting Data on the Map" (Dagstuhl Seminar 12261), which was accompanied by an exhibition combining art and science, aimed at the general public, “Bending Reality: Where Arc and Science Meet,” (http://www.dagstuhl.de/en/ueber­dagstuhl/kunst/bending­ reality/). Presentations were made at by­-invitation-­only events such as the Bertinoro Workshop on Graph Visualization and the Barbados Workshop on Computational Geometry. New courses on "Experimental Algorithms" and "Beyond Planar Graphs" were created and taught for the first time. 

Applications of our work can be found in word­cloud visualization and computational cartography. We developed the first approaches to semantics­ preserving word cloud visualization, which provide theoretical guarantees. The main challenge in generating word clouds is to attempt to preserve the semantics of the text, by placing as many of the semantically-related words close to each other. We also quantitatively evaluated our algorithms against several earlier heuristics (in terms of semantics preservation, layout distortion, compactness, etc.), showing that our new algorithms outperform the earlier methods in terms of semantic preservation, while not negatively impacting any of the other word cloud parameters (see Image "Word Clouds"). The fully functional system is available at http://wordcloud.cs.arizona.edu.

We designed and implemented new efficient algorithms for cartograms. A cartogram is a value-by-area diagram in which the geographic areas of countries on a map are modified in order to represent a given set of values, such as population in the well-known red-blue election maps of the US.
